entry.title: Closure and Lexical Environment
entry.content:
From the previous post, we see that in Java local variables accessed within closure must be declared final. Why is Java designed this way? To understand this problem, you must learn about lexical environment first.

As different languages do not always have a common definition of the lexical environment, their definitions of closure may vary also. The commonly held minimalist definition of the lexical environment defines it as a set of all bindings of variables in the scope, and that is also what closures in any language have to capture. However the meaning of a variable binding also differs. In imperative languages, variables bind to relative locations in memory that can store values. Although the relative location of a binding does not change at runtime, the value in the bound location can. In such languages, since closure captures the binding, any operation on the variable, whether done from the closure or not, are performed on the same relative memory location. This is often called capturing the variable “by reference”.

On the other hand, many functional languages, such as ML, bind variables directly to values. In this case, since there is no way to change the value of the variable once it is bound, there is no need to share the state between closures—they just use the same values. This is often called capturing the variable “by value”. Java’s local and anonymous classes also fall into this category—they require captured local variables to be final, which also means there is no need to share state.

There are at least two kind of lexical environments, “capture by reference” and “capture by value”. In Java, it’s “capture by value”. However, in C# and Python, it’s “capture by reference”.


The code above shows the complexity of closure that Java tries to avoid. The value of captured variable is determined when invoked. If you want to bind the value instead of reference, you must copy it inside the closure.

The line int copy = variable; will copy the value of variable into a new address, and this reference is bound into the closure. There are also similar examples in Python.

The property of closure in C# has a very interesting impact on the refresh of screen and the data behind. When developing WPF, you should refresh the canvas in the UI thread, while the data behind is usually retrieved in a non-UI thread. To draw on a canvas, you should call Canvas.Dispatcher.Invoke() with a first-class function. It’s interesting to study on how the dispatcher would behave when using different way to access outside variables within the closure.

entry.title: War Against Null IV - Closure In Consumer
entry.content:
When you “consume” the Optional instance when it’s present, or call map() or orElseGet(), you have to create a lambda expression to be invoked. When it comes to passing a first-class function, you will encounter the concept of closure. In Java 8, variables you capture in the closure must be declared with final, which means there’s no way to modify it within the lambda expression. For example, the code below won’t compile:


You will get a tip from IDEA:

Variables used in lambda expression should be final or effectively final.

I don’t know what it means by effectively final by now. If you use the IDE to fix it, the code becomes:


The snippet above uses an 1-length array as a container for the variable you want to modify in the closure. This workaround is a little anti-intuitive. And you must use the array every time you want to use the contained variable. And this workaround is the same when you want to modify a outside local variable within an anonymous inner class, because lambda expressions in Java are intrinsically anonymous inner classes.

But why do we need declare the local variable final? Below are some discussions I found in stackoverflow.

Not quite true, Java does generate captures for the variables in question to capture their run-time values, its just they wanted to avoid a strange side-effect that is possible in .Net where by you capture the value in the delegate, change the value in the outer method, and now the delegate sees the new value see, stackoverflow.com/questions/271440/c-captured-variable-in-loop for the C# example of this behaviour that Java aims to avoid.

Java does not, in fact, support closures. Languages that support closures do so by storing the entire local environment (that is, the set of local variables defined in the current stack frame) as a heap object. Java doesn’t have support for this (the language designers wanted to implement it but ran out of time), so as a workaround, whenever a local class is instantiated, the values of any local variables which it refers to are copied onto the heap. However, the JVM can’t then keep the values in sync with the local variables, which is why they have to be final.

The explanation (or background) for this answer is wrong, stating that the objects created inside a method (local context) are destroyed after the method execution ends (and its context is removed from the stack) is not correct, local VARIABLES will be destroyed (removed from the stack), but the objects they reference (in the case of reference variables) will remain in the heap until the gc runs and there are no more strong references to this object. The reason this actually happens has to do with the way the java compiler works, please see my answer for an explanation.

that explanation of things is misleading. There is no practical difference between “real” closures and Java’s workaround. It’s just more convenient to create closures in languages that have better support for them. The final requirement is an inconvenience, nothing more: it doesn’t mean the object can’t be mutable. A claim to the contrary should demonstrate what’s possible with “real” closures that isn’t possible in Java’s implementation.

entry.title: War Against Null II - If Not Present
entry.content:
As is mentioned in my last post, Optional<T>.ifPresent() could combine the check of nullity and the use of wrapped content in one step, which avoid the possibility of raising NPEs. However, there’s some trouble when the Optional object wraps a null.

OrElse

There is a Optional<T>.orElse(T other) method which returns the wrapped value if it presents or returns the default value. However, remember the example of my last post? I need to print the name of a specified id or output “id not found” now. We can call nullableName.orElse("id not found" to return the msg if it’s not present. However, is there a way to work for both situations, as the traditional code snippet below does?

Map Plus OrElse

If you analyze the code snippet above, it represents a mapping from a nullable String name to a non-null String msg. Let’s change a way of understanding, you can break the mapping into 2 parts. First, map nullable String name to nullable String msgIfPresent, and then map nullable String msgIfPresent to non-null String msg. The second mapping is exactly what orElse() does. So you only need to complete the first mapping. Optional<T>.map() is the solution we need.


The code above first map Optinal<String> nullableName to another Optional<String> object. The lambda expression in the map() methods means that if name presents, you get a new Optional<String> whose content is the value of the mapped expression. And if not, you will still get an empty Optional<String>. So the string you get after this mapping is “name is …” or null. And then Optional<T>.orElse() will handle with the null possibility. It returns a default value if the content is null, or the content itself. The orElse() call successfully map null and non-null possibilities into a concrete value.

Question

However, does this method work for every cases when you want to execute different code based on whether it’s null or non-null?

entry.title: War Against Null I - Simulate Optional Class in Java 7
entry.content:
A Billion-Dollar Mistake

I call it my billion-dollar mistake. It was the invention of the null reference in 1965. At that time, I was designing the first comprehensive type system for references in an object oriented language (ALGOL W). My goal was to ensure that all use of references should be absolutely safe, with checking performed automatically by the compiler. But I couldn’t resist the temptation to put in a null reference, simply because it was so easy to implement. This has led to innumerable errors, vulnerabilities, and system crashes, which have probably caused a billion dollars of pain and damage in the last forty years. - Tony Hoare

Optional in Java 8

As is stated by its inventor, Tony Hoare, null reference has caused innumerable errors. In Android, NPE is like a lurking demon which appears here and there and crashes the app. There have been lots of methods to avoid potential null problems in compile time. From Java 8 and on, you can create an Optional<T> class to wrap the object may be null, and execute code inside the lambda expression.

For example, below is a method which delegates Map.get() which returns Optional<String>:


And for the client, you use the result like this:

Simulate One in Java 7

In this example, you print the name of a specified id if it’s not null. In Android, there are lots of methods returning null and producing potential exceptions like findViewById(), findFragmentByTag() and so on. However, the Android sdk doesn’t support features in Java 8, except you use a plugin to get over it. To solve this problem, you can simulate the lambda function by a functional interface, and use anonymous inner classes to pass the function body. The function is called Consumer.


Below is a simplest Optional implementation:

In Android, you can use this class to wrap a listener, like:

In this way, you forward the event to the nullable listener, which will only handle the event when presenting.

The Benefits

Why do we use a lambda expression or an anonymous inner class to handle the null cases, instead of straightfoward !=null check? Or should we use Optional.isPresent() to check if the object exists? The key of this approach is that the calling of a lambda expression or an anonymous inner class is like an atomic operation. You have to check the nullity and execute the operation in one step and you have not any chance to forget. This is the true power of Optional class.

However, there are also some problems for this approach to deal with null references. I will introduce them in future articles.

entry.title: Fuse Android Components with MVP
entry.content:
Service

In MVP pattern, service plays the role of model. Take a music player app as an example, a service playbacks music like a music player. A presenter should get a music player instance to deal with the logic behind. It’s easy to get an instance of a bound service inside the presenter.

Where to bind service?

Since views in MVP pattern should not concern about the inner logic and models. You should not bind the service in an activity or a fragment. When you bind a service, you only need a context, so you should receive a context in the constructor of the presenter.


In this way, you can get the instance of the bound service inside the presenter. And the service should implement the interface of model, like IRecorder in this example.

Broadcast Receiver

A broadcast receiver forwards the event upon it receives an intent. The receiver itself is independent, but should hold an instance of the listener. It can declare an interface for listeners, like:


And the presenter can simply implement this interface above, so you can handle the event inside the presenter.

ListView and Adapter

It’s pretty difficult to deal with ListView, RecyclerView and their adapters. Because the adapter itself is a concept very similar to the presenter. For the adapter of RecyclerView, the creation of item ViewHolders should be with the scope of views, and the binding of data for items should be the work of presenter. And event handling for items should be within the presenter. I will post up detailed code later.

entry.title: Create Android Apps with MVP
entry.content:
As is well known, traditional Android app development generally follows the MVC pattern. However, an activity or a fragment usually acts as the role of both a view and a controller. As a result, the code is tightly coupled and the complexity of activities and fragments are explosive. It’s difficult to reuse the logic behind.

Model-View-Presenter(MVP) is a solution to this problem. The idea of MVP is similar to dependency injection. Different components of the framework should not have the knowledge of the concrete implementation of the dependencies they need. Activities or fragments should only act as the role of view. So let’s start with them.

User Interface

We start with a very simple app, an accumulator, which receives a number and add into a stored number of itself.

First think about the Views we need. We need an input EditText to take a number from user, a TextView to display the result, a Button to invoke the adding, and a Button to reset the accumulator. These Views could be contained directly in an activity or in a content fragment. Let’s take a fragment as example:

View

Then we should design the ‘view’ of MVP. A view may have 2 functions, to display information inside the program, and/or to receive input from the user. We now only concern with the first function. The display part of the accumulator app is very simple. We only need to display the current stored number of accumulator. Because we don’t care about which view shows the result, we only need to define an interface.


In order to make our activity/fragment act as the view, we should implement the interface. So we modify the code of MainActivityFragment into:

The fragment uses the TextView inside it to display the result, but who uses INumberView has no idea about it.

Presenter

Our view implementation should not know about the model it displays. This is achieved by a middle-man, presenter. A presenter should handle the events from views, notify the models, and then report the result back to views. So a presenter should take a view and related models as argument.


In order to forward the events from views, presenter must implement interfaces to handle the events. Our app only has two events, submitting the number and resetting.
So the interface is like this:

After the presenter receives events, it should call the model and view it holds to execute the logic.

Model

The concrete implementation of models should also be hidden. So we need define the behaviors of models in interfaces.


Models should simply be POJOs.

Assemble

After we created the interfaces, we could start assemble them together. The place we assemble them should be within the activity or fragment, since they’re the entrance of an Android app. And the activity or fragment should hold the reference of the presenter. Inside the fragment:

Note: The model is provided via dependency injection.

Forward Events

The last procedure is to forward the events of views to the presenter. Just do it in the Listener class. You can create separate listeners or implement the activity/fragment as a listener.

So the above is all the code related to the MVP pattern in our simple example. As we can see, it’s very powerful to decouple model, view and the logic with them. With dependency injection, the code could be extremely flexible and reusable.

entry.title: Dependency Injection - Configuration and Injector
entry.content:
Today, after learning about the dependency injection, I refactored my code in the forementioned project. I used constructor injection for all the classes which require services. The client which needs a service/dependency doesn’t produce it by itself. It gets an instance from the constructor instead.

The nested object hierarchy becomes clearer in this way. For example, a class Computer must receive trivial params like double caseWeight, int fanNumber, String cpuBrand and so on. A Computer constructor may take tens of arguments to get initialized. Because inside the Computer construtor, it produces its components, like this.case = new Case(caseSize, caseColor,cpuFanSize, cpuFanSpeed, cpuBrand, cpuCoreNum, diskSize);. All params of lower level objects must be passed from the upper level.

Without Dependency Injection

A typical verbose constructor may be like this:


Inside the constructor of Case:

And inside the constructor of CPU:

And then inside the constructor of CpuFan:

With Dependency Injection

After using dependency injection, the Computer constructor may be like this：


And the constructors of Case, CPU and CpuFan will also be simplified, for they take components from outside rather than build it themselves.

However, at the topmost level, you still need to construct all the objects and assemble them. How to make this procedure easier?

The solution is using an injector class and a configuration class/file. First, list all the params into a configuration class. It may be a singleton or a global variable container, it’s like:


All configurable params could be put into this config class or different classes. The value of each param could be read from a configuration file.

And then create an injector/factory/assembler class, to provide interface implementation based on the configurations.


In this way, all object creation work is done by the Injector class. And all details about objects are contained in the Configs class. We can modify the implementation details easily using different params or subtypes, without affecting the code of clients. Every client only concerns about the service/dependency it uses directly, and the dependency itself is also a client. This Injector class acts like a factory, which produces all the components to be used. None of the clients produces components themselves. This is the power of dependency injection.

Note: Since all objects receive the dependency/service from the constructor, all injection work should be done at the topmost level of the object hierarchy

entry.title: Dependency Injection - 实现
entry.content:
本文主要内容翻译自https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_injection

不使用依赖注入

在下面的Java例子中，客户类包含一个作为field的服务，后者通过客户的构造器初始化。客户控制了使用服务的哪个具体实现，并控制了其创建。在这个情景下，客户对ServiceExample有了hard-coded的依赖。


依赖注入是一个替代的技术，可以初始化field而不显式地创建服务对象。

三种依赖注入

一个对象至少有三种方法来获取外部模组的引用。

  • 构造器注入：通过类的构造器提供依赖。
  • setter注入：客户暴露一个setter方法，注射器使用该方法来注入依赖。
  • 接口注入：依赖提供一个注射器方法，将依赖注入进传递给它的任何客户。客户必须实现一个暴露了接收依赖的setter方法的接口。

构造器注入

这个方法要求客户在构造器中为依赖提供参数。

Setter注入

这个方法要求客户为每个依赖提供一个setter方法。

接口注入

客户为客户依赖的setter方法发布一个角色接口。可以用来设置，注射器在注入依赖时如何与客户沟通。

构造器注入的优缺点

当所有依赖都在最开始构造时使用。它可以确保客户端对象总是处在有效的状态，避免了一些依赖引用为null的情况（未被设置）。然而，这种方法欠缺了随后变更依赖的灵活性。这种方法可以作为使客户不可变，并线程安全的初始步骤。

Setter注入的优缺点

要求客户为每个依赖提供setter方法。这样做赋予了在任何时候操作依赖引用的状态的自由。它提供了灵活性，但如果有多个依赖将被注入，客户很难确保所有的依赖都在客户可使用之前被注入。


因为这些注入互相独立，所以没有办法来获知，什么时候注射器完成了客户的装配。注射器调用setter失败时，某个依赖可能被留作null。无论何时，客户被使用时，都必须检查注射是否完成。

接口注入的优缺点

接口注入的优点是依赖可以完全无视其客户，同时仍然可以接收新客户的引用，使用并将自身引用返回给客户。这种方法中，依赖成为了注射器。关键是，注射方法（可以为经典的setter方法）是通过接口提供的。

这种方法仍需要组装器来引入客户和他的依赖。组装器拿到客户的引用，将其cast到设置依赖的setter接口，然后传递给依赖对象，后者将自身的引用传回给客户端。

组装的例子

在main中手动组装是实现依赖注入的一种方法。


这个例子手动地构建了对象图，并在一个点上调用使之开始工作。要注意的是，这个注射器并非纯净的。它使用了它所一个创建的对象。它与ServiceExample拥有单纯的创建关系，但混合了Client的创建和使用。这不应该常见。但它是无法避免的。就好像面向对象的软件需要一个非面向对象的static方法，如main()来启动，一个依赖注入对象图需要至少一个（最好仅有一个）入口点来启动使用。

在main方法中手动创建可能并非如上面例子一样straightforward，可能包含了调用builders, factories, 或者其他构造模式。这可以被相当地改进和抽象。一旦构造代码不再对应用可自定义，变得通用，手动的依赖注入就成为了框架依赖注入。

entry.title: Dependency Injection - 概览
entry.content:
上一篇我的英文文章中，提到了解决复杂对象层级中暴露大量参数的办法是依赖注入，这篇文章就先对依赖注入进行一下了解。

本文主要内容翻译自https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_injection

软件工程中，依赖注入是一种实现了控制反转的软件设计模式，用以解决依赖问题。依赖指的是一个可以被使用的对象，也称作服务。注入指的是将依赖传递给一个依靠它的对象（客户），即使用服务的对象。服务成为客户的状态的一部分。将服务传递给客户，而非允许客户创建或寻找服务，是这个模式的基本要求。

依赖注入允许程序设计遵循依赖反转原则。客户将提供依赖的责任委托给外部代码（注射器）。而客户不可以调用注射器代码。注射代码构造了服务，并调用客户将服务注入。这意味着客户代码无需知晓注射代码。客户无需知道如何创建服务。客户也无需知道实际使用的是哪个服务。这将使用和创建的责任分离开。

客户有三种常用的方法以接受依赖注入：setter注入，interface注入，constructor注入。setter和构造器注入主要的区别是他们被使用的时机。而接口注入有所不同的是，依赖可以获取控制其注入的机会。他们都要求单独的构造代码（注射器）负责引入客户和互相之间的依赖。

概览

依赖注入将客户的依赖的创建和客户的行为分离，使得程序设计实现松耦合，并遵从依赖反转和单一责任原则。它与服务定位模式正好相反，后者允许客户知晓查找依赖时使用的系统。

注入是依赖注入的基本单元，但它并非一个新的或自定义的机理。它与“参数传递”的工作方式相同。将“参数传递”看作一个注入，暗示了这个过程将把客户从细节隔离开。

注入也与控制着传递的事物（一定不是客户）有关，并且总是与传递是如何完成的无关，无论是传递引用还是指针。

依赖注入包括四个角色：

  • 一个或多个将被使用的服务对象
  • 一个依赖（使用）服务的客户对象
  • 一些定义了客户可能如何使用服务的接口
  • 一个负责创建服务并注入至客户的注射器

任何可能被使用的对象都可以被看作是一个服务。任何使用了其他对象的对象都可以看作是一个客户。这些名称与对象实际的作用无关，一切都与对象在一次注入中扮演的角色有关。

接口是客户所期待的依赖的类型。关键的问题是这些接口使什么成为可访问的。他们可能是服务所实现的真正的接口类型，也可能是抽象类，甚至是具体的服务自身。虽然后者会违反DIP，并且牺牲测试时需要的动态解耦。唯一要求的是，客户不知道他们是什么，从而不将他们视为具体类型，不创建或继承他们。

注射器将服务引入至客户。经常地，它也创建客户。注射器可能将非常复杂的对象图连接起来，通过将对象视作一个客户，并随后视作另一个客户所需的服务。注射器可能实际是许多在一起工作的对象，但不可以是客户。注射器可能被称作其他名称，如：assembler, provider, container, factory, builder, spring, construction code, main。

依赖注入可以被应用为一项原则，它要求所有对象分离创建创造和行为。依靠依赖注入框架来执行创建可以禁止使用new关键字，或者不严格地，只允许直接创建值对象。

Taxonomy

控制反转比依赖注入更加广泛。简单的说，控制反转意味着让其他代码调用你，而非总是执行调用。一个使用控制反转却没有使用依赖注入的例子是模板模式。这里通过子类实现了多态，也就是继承。

依赖注入通过组合实现了控制反转，所以常常与策略模式等同。但是策略模式主要是为了那些可以在对象的生命周期内进行变更的依赖，而依赖注入可能只有依赖的单个实例会被使用。这也实现了多态，但是是通过代理和组合。

优点

  • 依赖注入为客户提供了可配置的灵活性。只有客户的行为是固定的。客户可以使用任何支持所期待的接口的事物。
  • 依赖注入可以用来将系统的配置细节外置到配置文件中，使系统可以在不重新编译的情况下重新配置。可以为需要不同组件实现的不同的情景提供不同的配置。包括测试时。
  • 依赖注入并不要求改变代码行为，可以通过重构应用到旧的代码中。客户端会更加独立，而且更容易进行单元测试。
  • 依赖注入允许客户完全不知晓所需使用的服务的具体实现。这可以将客户与设计的改变和缺陷隔离开。它提升了重用性，可测试性和可维护性。
  • 减少了应用对象中的重复使用的模式化的代码。因为初始化或设立依赖的工作都由提供者进行处理。
  • 依赖注入允许并发或独立开发。两个开发者可以独立地开发互相调用的类，只需知道类之间通讯的接口。比如插件常常由第三方开发者开发，而无需与创建产品并使用插件的开发者进行沟通。
  • 依赖注入减少了类和其依赖之间的耦合。

缺点

  • 依赖注入创建的客户要求通过构造代码提供配置细节。而当存在明显的默认值时，会显得很繁琐。
  • 依赖注入可能会使得代码难以追踪，因为它将行为与创建分离开。开发者必须查阅更多的文件以获知系统如何工作。
  • 依赖注入要求更多的预先的开发工作，因为无法在需要某对象的时候和场景直接获取对象，而必须要求它进行注入，并确保已经完成注入。
  • 依赖注入可以造成类型的爆炸，尤其是拥有显式接口类型的语言，如Java和C#。
  • 依赖注入将复杂度强制移出类内，并放进类与类之间的联系之中，可能会导致管理的困难。
  • 讽刺的是，依赖注入鼓励了对依赖注入框架的依赖。

entry.title: Dependency Injection - Handle A Large Amount of Params with A Complex Class Hierarchy
entry.content:
I’m developing a complex desktop client with C#, which is mainly for some scientific analysis work. The class hierarchy of my project is very complicated. The problem is that, a large amount of parameters should be able to be modified by the user at the entrance of the client.

However, many parameters are very deep in the class hierarchy (I mean the composition hierarchy, not inheritance). As a result, classes closed to the top levels must take a lot of arguments in the constructor, because they are passed all the way up from different classes at the bottom levels.

What’s the best practices to handle problems like this? I have 3 ideas.

  1. Global static variables: Just create a Constants class and store these params as static fields, like Constants.FOO, Constants.BAR.
  2. Singleton class: Create a singleton class, and initialize it at the entrance of program. Get these params like Constants.GetInstance().FOO.
  3. For every class, receive lower-level params in the constructor, which makes the constructor signature verbose and complicated. For example, a mid-level frequently-used class may take 15 arguments in the constructor.

If I use global variables or a singleton too often, the code will become very coupled. But if I do not use them, lots of params must be passed and received along the class hierarchy again and again. So how would a complicated commercial software do to solve this problem?

For example, the program creates a LevelOne object at the topmost level. The LevelOne contains fields like LevelTwoA and LevelTwoB. And a LevelTwoA object contains fields like LevelThree and so on. Then if the user wants to specify the value of a LevelTen field when creating the LevelOne, the value of LevelTen must be passed from the constructor of LevelOne to LevelNine.

And take a Car as an example, what if the user want to specify the Radius of a certian Gear when creating a Car? The Gear object must be at the bottom level of the whole hierarchy. However, a Car should not take a double radiusOfACertianGear as an argument in its constructor, because it’s too trivial.

The solution is dependency injection. I will introduce it in the next post.

entry.title: Record Audio on Wearable Devices
entry.content:
Wearable devices have great potential in our everyday life. For example, you can simply tap the watch screen or speak a command to wake up the watch and start recording, and then transmit the recorded clip to the phone for storage. This article will put down the procedures of developing a watch recorder.

Create a Recorder

Recording on wearable devices is basically the same as handheld devices, except that you cannot use MediaRecorder APIs for wearable devices. Instead, you must use AudioRecord to record voice. The implementation of AudioRecord is completely same as handheld devices. You can read my article for reference, Recording with AudioRecord APIs in Android

Collect Data in Bytes

Instead of saving data stream to a File while recording in handheld devices, you should store all raw data together and then send it to your phone.


With a ByteArrayOutputStream(), you could store data bytes while recording. Remember to call it in a background thread after recording started.

Send Message to Handheld devices

With Wearable.MessageApi, you could send bytes data to other devices easily. You only need to specify a path for message and retrieve an available device id.

Register a Listener for the Target Device

The target activity which receives the data must implement a MessageApi.MessageListener and register it to a GoogleApiClient.


Then implement the onMessageReceived(MessageEvent) callback to handle the event. The snippet below plays the audio data once received.

Retrieve Available Devices

You should declare a capability name for a target node which is able to respond to the request from your wearable device. The capability is declared in res/values/wear.xml like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <string-array name="android_wear_capabilities">
        <item>voice_playback</item>
    </string-array>
</resources>

And then the snippet below retrieves available nodes by the pre-declared capability name.


After retrieving an available node, you could send the message to it as is mentioned in previous sessions.

entry.title: Summary on Implementing a Navigation Drawer
entry.content:
The navigation drawer is an indispensable component in Android apps under the guidance of Material Design. It’s very convenient to implement a navigation drawer by creating a DrawerLayout with a NavigationView in it with the material design support library. However, when it comes to ‘navigation’, you should consider carefully how to implement the navigation action with drawer menu items.

A Base Activity vs Fragments

Should we implement different pages as different activities, or just an Activity with dynamically loaded fragments? In my opinion, both ways are okay.

Using Fragments

pros:

  • Only one layout is needed. Fragments could be added to the layout container dynamically.
  • Switching among fragments is very fast and smooth.
  • More flexible when adapting different devices.

cons:

  • Too many possible contents are displayed by one activity, increasing the complexity of some operations on the activity.
  • You need to realize the synchronization between fragments and other activity components. For example, the backstack, the checked item, the correct title, etc.

Using A Base Activity

pros:

  • Code could be inherited by all its subclasses.
  • It’s more flexible to change the UI for different activities.
  • No need to manage navigation states manually.

cons:

  • Switching among activities is much slower, even you implement a custom animation for transition.

Sync States with the Backstack

It’s easy to add fragment transitions into the backstack by calling .addToBackStack(null) before .comit(). However, after user presses the back button, the fragment is switched back successfully while the action bar or toolbar title, the checked item in the drawer menu and other information relating to the foreground fragment is not switched at the same time. You must implement the synchronization for the backstate to get the best user experience.

Mark fragments with Tags

One way to solve this problem is by tagging the fragment. After user presses the back button, check which fragment is now on the foreground, and retrieve its tag. So you can override onBackPressed() like this:

Add a Listener to the FragmentManager

You can also add a listener to the FragmentManager and then retrieve the last fragment.

Use a Base Activity

If you want to implement the same navigation drawer for all the pages of your app, (I’m not sure whether it’s a good idea though), displaying all pages in one page make the code complicated and error-prone. So you could implement a base activity to handle the navigation drawer.

entry.title: Record with AudioRecord APIs in Android
entry.content:
I want to make an audio recorder app for my Android Wear device. In order to get familiar with the recording APIs of the Android platform, I will start with a simple mobile app, and then move it into my moto 360.

APIs

Two sets of audio recording APIs, MediaRecorder and AudioRecord, are available for developing handheld apps. MediaRecorder is much easy to use, however it’s unavailable for wearable devices. So you must process the raw data from AudioRecord by yourself.

Find a Proper Audio Configuration

You must get a proper set of arguments to initialize an AudioRecord object. Different devices support different configurations, however, there’s not any method to get the supported configuration of your device directly. You must query all possible combinations to find an valid one.

Declare Permissions

Don’t forget to declare the permissions. When developing for Marshmellow, remember to require runtime permission, or you can’t create a valid AudioRecord.

<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.RECORD_AUDIO" />
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>

Start Recording

After creating a valid AudioRecord, you can call AudioRecord.startRecording() to start recording. During recording, you should:

  1. Use a flag to indicate that recording has been started.
  2. Write recorded data to file immediately and continuously in background.

Stop Recording

When stopping, don’t forget to mark the flag and call release().

Play Recorded Clips

Most music players on Android could not play a .pcm file. Instead, you should write a simple PCM player using AudioTrack class.

A Sample Recorder

entry.title: Android Wear 开发 （十四） 处理数据层事件
entry.content:
调用数据层API时，可以在完成时获取调用的状态，也可以侦听调用引起的任何改变。

等待数据层调用的状态

数据层API有时返回一个PendingResult，比如putDataItem()。一旦PendingResult创建，操作会在后台被入队。如果在这之后什么也不做，操作最终会静默地完成。然而，一般情况下都想在操作完成后根据结果做些什么，所以PendingResult可以让你等待结果的状态，同步或异步地。

异步调用

如果代码运行在UI线程，不要调用数据层API的阻塞方法。可以通过向PendingResult添加一个回调方法来运行异步调用，它将在操作完成后启用。

同步调用

如果代码运行在后台服务里单独的handler线程，如WearableListenerService，那么调用阻塞的方法没有问题。这种情况下，应该调用PendingResult的await()方法，它将阻塞直到请求完成，并返回一个Result对象。

侦听数据层事件

因为数据层在手机和手表间同步并且发送数据，一般需要侦听一些重要的事件，比如数据项被创建时，消息被接收时，或者手表或手机被连接时。

要侦听数据层事件，有两种选择：

  • 创建一个service继承WearableListenerService。
  • 创建一个activity实现DataApi.DataListener。

两种方法都可以重写希望处理的数据事件回调方法。

WearableListenerService

一般在手机和手表中都需要创建service的实例。如果对其中的一个中的数据事件不感兴趣，那么不需要实现相应的service。

例如，手机应用可以设置和获取数据项对象，而手表应用可以侦听这些更新来刷新自己的UI。这个手表永远都不会更新任何的数据项，所以手机应用无需侦听手表应用的数据项事件。

可以用WearableListenerService侦听下面的事件：

  • onDataChanged() - 当数据项对象被创建，改变或删除时调用。连接一侧的事件会在两侧都触发调用。
  • onMessageReceived() - 从连接一侧发送的消息在连接的另一侧触发回调。
  • onPeerConnected()和onPeerDisconnected() - 连接建立或断开时调用。连接一侧的连接状态的改变在两侧都触发回调。

要创建一个WearableListenerService：

  1. 创建一个继承WearableListenerService的类；
  2. 侦听感兴趣的事件，比如onDataChanged()；

  3. 在manifest中生命一个intent filter来告知系统自己的WearableListenerService。这将允许系统按需要绑定service。

    下面是manifest中对应的intent filter：

    数据层回调的权限

    要向应用发送数据层事件的回调，Google Play服务绑定至WearableListenerService，并且通过IPC调用回调。这导致了回调继承了调用进程的权限。

如果试图在回调中执行特权的操作，安全检查可能会失败。因为回调以调用进程的身份运行，而非应用的进程。

要解决这个问题，调用clearCallingIdentity()，在穿过IPC边界后重置身份，并且在完成了特权操作后调用restoreCallingIdentity()以恢复身份。

Listener Activity

如果应用只有当用户与应用交互时关心数据层事件，不需要使用长期运行的service来处理所有数据改变，可以在activity中通过实现下面的一个或多个接口来侦听事件：

  • DataApi.DataListener
  • MessageApi.MessageListener
  • NodeApi.NodeListener

要创造一个侦听数据事件的activity：

  1. 实现想要的接口；
  2. 在onCreate(Bundle)中创建GoogleApiClient的一个实例来使用数据层API；
  3. 在onStart()调用connect()来连接客户端至Google Play服务；
  4. 连接至Google Play服务之后，系统调用onConnected()。在这里调用DataApi.addListener(), MessageApi.addListener(), 或 NodeApi.addListener()来告知Google Play服务，当面activity希望侦听数据层事件。
  5. 在onStop()中调用DataApi.removeListener(), MessageApi.removeListener(), 或 NodeApi.removeListener()注销任意的侦听器。

  6. 根据实现的接口实现onDataChanged(), onMessageReceived(), onPeerConnected(), 和onPeerDisconnected().

entry.title: Android Wear 开发 （十三） 发送接收消息
entry.content:
使用MessageApi来发送消息，并将下面的子项附给消息：

  • 一个任意的payload（可选）
  • 一个标识了消息动作的路径

与数据项不同，手机和手表应用之间没有同步。消息是单方向的通讯机制，适合RPC操作，比如向手表发送一条消息以启动一个activity。

许多手表设备可以被连接至用户的手机。网络中每个被连接的设备都可以看作一个节点。有多个连接的设备时，必须考虑由哪个节点来接受消息。例如，一个在手表上接收语音数据进行转录的应用，必须将消息发送至有足够处理能力和电池容量的节点来处理请求，比如一台手机。

发送消息

用户可以对手表的麦克风讲话，然后转换成为一条笔记。因为手表一般没有足够的处理能力和电池容量，所以转录的任务应该交给更加强力的连接的设备。

宣告能力

要通过手表在手机上启动一个activity，需要使用MessageApi类来发送请求。因为多个手表可能连接至手机，手表应用需要判定一个节点是否有能力启动activity。在手机上，宣告本节点运行的设备提供指定的能力。

要宣告手机应用的能力：

  1. 在res/values目录中创建一个XML配置文件，命名为wear.xml。
  2. 在其中添加一个android_wear_capabilities资源。
  3. 定义设备提供的能力。

能力是你所自定义的字符串，必须在应用中独一无二。

<resources>
    <string-array name="android_wear_capabilities">
        <item>voice_transcription</item>
    </string-array>

获取有能力的节点

首先，可以通过调用CapabilityApi.getCapability()方法来探测可用的节点。


要在连接到手表上时探测可用的节点，可以向GoogleApiClient注册一个CapabilityApi.CapabilityListener()实例。

探测可用节点之后，决定发送消息的对象。应该选择一个最临近的节点以缩短消息发送的路径。直接连接到设备的节点定义为邻近节点。调用Node.isNearby()方法可以判定是否为邻近节点。

与数据项不同，手机和手表应用之间没有同步。消息是单方向的通讯机制，适合RPC操作，比如向手表发送一条消息以启动一个activity。

许多手表设备可以被连接至用户的手机。网络中每个被连接的设备都可以看作一个节点。有多个连接的设备时，必须考虑由哪个节点来接受消息。例如，一个在手表上接收语音数据进行转录的应用，必须将消息发送至有足够处理能力和电池容量的节点来处理请求，比如一台手机。

entry.title: Android Wear 开发 （十二） 传输Assets
entry.content:
要通过蓝牙发送较大的二进制数据块，比如图片，可以为数据项附加一个Asset，并将数据项添加至复制的数据商店。

Assets自动处理数据的缓存，来阻止重复传送，并节省蓝牙带宽。一个通用的模式是，在手机应用上下载图片，缩小至适合手表显示的尺寸，然后作为asset传送至手表上。

数据项的大小限制在100KB，而asset则可以尽可能的大。然而，传输大asset会影响用户体验，所以传输时一定要做好测试工作来确保其表现。

entry.title: Android Wear 开发 （十一） 同步数据项
entry.content:
DataItem定义了系统用来在手机和手表间同步数据的数据接口。它通常包含了：

  • Payload - 一个字节数组，可以设置任何数据，可以自己进行对象序列化和反序列化。其大小限制在100KB。
  • Path - 一个独特的字符串，必须以一个前斜杠开始，如(/path/to/data)。

一般不需要直接实现DataItem。只需：

  1. 创建一个PutDataRequest对象，指定一个字符串路径来标识该项目。
  2. 调用setData()来设置payload。
  3. 如果同步的延迟会影响用户体验，调用setUrgent()。
  4. 调用DataApi.putDataItem()。

实测表明，不调用setUrgent()的话，手机向手表发送请求时，双方响应非常快。而手表向手机发送时，只有手表处马上响应，手机处则非常慢。

在请求数据项时，系统返回正确实现了DataItem接口的对象。然而，并不推荐使用setData()直接设置原生的字节，建议使用data map，它用一个容易使用的类似Bundle的接口来暴露数据。

用data map同步数据

尽可能使用DataMap类。系统会自动进行对象的序列化和反序列化，像Bundle一样。

  1. 创建PutDataMapRequest对象，为数据项设定路径。

    注意：路径字符串是连接的两侧用来访问数据项的独特的标识符。如果在应用中使用了阶层式的数据，应该创建一个path scheme来匹配数据的阶层。

  2. 调用PutDataMapRequest.getDataMap()来获取一个可以设置值的data map。

  3. 调用put...()方法设置值。
  4. 如果延迟会影响用户体验，调用setUrgent()。
  5. 调用PutDataMapRequest.asPutDataRequest()来获取一个PutDataRequest对象。
  6. 调用DataApi.putDataItem来请求系统创建数据项。

    注意：如果手机和手表断开连接，数据将被缓存，并在连接重新建立后进行同步。

increaseCounter()方法展示了如果创建data map并放入数据：

侦听数据项事件

如果数据层连接的一侧改变了某个数据项，应该在另一侧也获取通知。这只需实现数据项事件的侦听器即可：


Activity实现了DataItemt.DataListener接口，在onConnected()方法中添加自身作为数据项事件的侦听器，并在onPause()方法中移除。

同样也可以用service作为侦听器。
